"Seairth Jacobs" <seairth@...> writes:

> From: "Nic Ferrier" <nferrier@...>
> 
> > I've always wondered why an authentication response couldn't have an
> > entity associated with it, either in the response body or referenced
> > via some content-location like header.
> >
> > If it were possible to associate an entity with the authentication
> > then browsers could render it when they find it and use the standard
> > dialog box when they don't.
> 
> Actually, 401 can have an entity in the response[1].  Unfortunately, it's
> intended to be displayed only when a login attempt fails.

Yes, sorry. That was my point. I just wasn't terribly clear.

 
> In truth, the dialog box bothers me less and less.  I think the browser
> makers could dress it up a bit, making it look more like a feature of the
> browser instead of a out-of-place dumpy dialog box.

I don't think that's true, the exact means by which users authenticate
will always need to be under application control because clients like
it that way. I don't know many websites that use basic auth now, but
ones that offer "login" forms abound, and not just for non-techies.

Even from a webservices perspective my suggested change to the 401
behaviour looks useful: a server might want to supply to a client a
page describing the authentication system to be used. Maybe a user
token can be obtained from an ldap server somewhere, or something
like that.


> As for the 'logout' bit, I think this gets back to some of the theories
> behind REST itself.  My understanding is that 401 allows you to
> *authenticate*, not *log in*.  "Logging in" implies maintaining some form of
> server-side session state, which is a big REST no-no (at least as I
> understand it).  In this view, it makes sense that there would not be a
> corresponding "logout" ability.

It depends what you mean by "login" doesn't it  /8->

Does REST really require that there be no server maintained state at
all? I thought the problem was how the association between server and
client is done: if it's done RESTfully (one way would be by
authentication) then it's ok isn't it?


Nic
